comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: This is a composite image by Frank Hurley. The "three observation balloons above the white cloud" do not appear on the original negative in the collection of the National Library of Australia. See what I wrote about it here: lifeasdaddy.typepad.com/lifeasdaddy/2008/09/the-unmistaka...

comment.author: 81392520@N00
comment._content:
Yeah, Hurley and his composites. I was always scandalised by them when I was younger, and I'm still not sure what I feel about them now.

But undeniably they are always beautiful, despite their heartbreaking source.

comment.author: 24479299@N06
comment._content: Absolutely fantastic image! They went with songs to the battle, they were young. Straight of limb, true of eyes, steady and aglow. They were staunch to the end against odds uncounted, They fell with their faces to the foe. They shall grow not old, as we that are left grow old: Age shall not weary them, nor the years condemn. At the going down of the sun and in the morning, We will remember them Laurence Binyon "For the Fallen"

comment.author: 62379908@N00
comment._content: This picture worries me.  Even in 1918, soldiers knew that when they group together they offer the enemy a better target.  Marching in a line in a combat zone makes enemy machine gunners very happy.  A single morter shell could take out a dozen soldiers in that formation.  At the very least, they should have left 10 meters between soldiers.

comment.author: 11299198@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/howard33] Frank Hurley was renowned for photos which gave a flavour of the battle without actually being under fire, ie staged and away from the front line. He was, as were many at this time, a great combiner of images taken at the front line to join many moments in one image which conveyed the idea he wanted.
